key_title: Key to the species of Atriplex

Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Chenopodiaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Chenopodiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Chenopodiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plant prostrate, monoecious, fleshy, covered with watery bladder-hairs; seed (at maturity) aligned at right angles to the urceolate bracteoles (subgenus Theleophyton)

Plants erect to prostrate, monoecious or dioecious, not or hardly fleshy, glabrous or scurfy from a covering of deflated bladder-hairs; seed parallel to bracteoles (except sometimes in the uncommon A. hortensis) (subgenus Atriplex)

Fruiting bracteoles united to just below the apex, thick and spongy almost throughout, or (in A. lindleyi subsp. conduplicata) dorsiventrally flattened with broad vertical wings, dorsal appendages absent; monoecious plants (section Spongiocarpus)
Fruiting bracteoles free or largely united, lacking or having only a thin spongy layer, but occasionally with pithy dorsal appendages; monoecious or dioecious plants
Annuals with ribbed stems; leaves herbaceous ('juicy'), flat, with open venation; lower leaves commonly opposite
Perennials; leaves usually of rather dryish texture, with closed, dark green netted venation
Fruiting bracteoles rotund, c. 10 mm long and wide, papery, but some female flowers lacking bracteoles; uncommon, erect herb of horticulture (section Atriplex)
Fruiting bracteoles deltoid to rhomboid, 3–7 mm long, often thickening with age, sometimes with dorsal tubercles (section Teutliopsis)
Lower leaves truncate, hastate or sagittate at base; upper leaves triangular or ovate
Lower leaves at least somewhat tapered at base; upper leaves commonly linear

Fruiting bracteoles developing a thin spongy layer with age, with shining superficial cells usually obvious under Ã— 10 magnification; commonly with a pair of dorsal warty protuberances; occasional native herb of saltmarshes and other saline soils
Fruiting bracteoles remaining thin and membranous at maturity; dorsal appendages absent; uncommon to rare garden weed
Erect or suberect perennial shrubs, dioecious (rarely otherwise male plants with some female flowers); male flowers in clusters within spikes or panicles (section Dialysex)
Low-growing annuals or perennials, monoecious; male flowers clustered in upper axils or short terminal spikes (section Semibaccatae)

Fruiting bracteoles with several spine-like appendages attached around the margin of a central dorsal protuberance; bracteoles united for less than half their total length; rare, prostrate subshrub of north-central Victoria
Fruiting bracteoles lacking dorsal appendages, or when present, appendages not spine-like; bracteoles united for at least half their length (rarely less than half in A. semibaccata and A. suberecta)
Bracteoles of unequal length, the adaxial shorter than abaxial and bearing a pair of wrinkled appendages toward the base
Bracteoles equal
United part of bracteoles forming a cylindric tube for the greater part
Bracteoles flattened or biconvex, occasionally with a short, basal, cylindric portion
Bracteoles 4–6-lobed at apex, the lobes horn-like, fan-shaped or reduced to small teeth
Bracteoles entire or shallowly toothed at apex
Bracteoles free and broadly rhombic, fan-shaped or reniform near apex
Bracteoles united to apex, remaining ± narrow throughout
Leaves petiolate, mostly more than 20 mm long
Leaves sessile, mostly less than 20 mm long
Bracteoles cylindric except for the flattened, but often dilated apex, not or hardly wider at apex, mostly less than 2.5 mm wide
Bracteoles cylindric in lower third, flattened above and cuneate, 2.5–4 mm wide at apex
Bracteoles with dorsal appendages or protuberances (occasionally lacking on some bracteoles)
Bracteoles without dorsal appendages or protuberances
Fruiting bracteoles 1–1.5 mm long; leaves to 7 mm long
Fruiting bracteoles and leaves longer than above
Bracteoles remaining grey-green, indistinctly veined or net-veined when dry; procumbent to erect, shrubby annual or perennial
Bracteoles usually red and semi-succulent when ripe, prominently 3–5-nerved when dry; prostrate to procumbent perennial
Bracteoles distinctly longer than wide; leaves entire to shallowly sinuate
Bracteoles about as long as wide; leaves acutely toothed or lobed
Bracteole appendages 1–4 (commonly 2), warty or subconical
Bracteole appendages numerous, finger-like
Bracteoles reniform or cordate, with a long, slender stipe
Bracteoles ovate to deltoid, sessile or subsessile
Bracteoles with inflated, spongy dorsal appendages (occasionally lacking from some fruits)
Bracteoles without inflated spongy appendages
Leaves elliptic to oblong
Leaves deltoid to cordate, broadly elliptic or orbicular
Leaves concolorous, silvery or grey-green on both surfaces; female flowers in axillary clusters
Leaves discolorous, glabrous above, densely mealy and whitish beneath; female flowers mostly in terminal spikes or panicles
Leaves rhombic to orbicular; bracteoles thin and papery toward apical margin
Leaves cordate to deltoid; bracteoles thickened and corky all over
Fruiting bracteoles cup-shaped, top-shaped or dorsiventrally flattened, with a horizontal or vertical wing-like appendage
Fruiting bracteoles globular to obovoid with no wing-like appendages
Leaves petiolate; bracteoles globular to obovoid, 8–12 mm long
Leaves subsessile to shortly petiolate; bracteoles ± globular, 4–6(–8) mm long
